page.title: Quantifiers and QP - Degree Words
page.introduction: Other quantifiers, like many, much, and few, come in a different position in the nominal phrase. In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in a few sad children or Sue's many black dogs. Further, these quantifiers can be modified by degree words such as very and so, as in very many dogs or so much waste.

form.prompt: Key examples of this type of quantifier in your language here:

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have degree words which can modify this type of quantifier?

form.prompt: Key your examples containing degree words here. Note that these degree words will most likely not be the same as the ones which can modify an entire nominal phrase dealt with in the first section above.

radioGroup.prompt: Based on these examples, where do the degree words (optionally) occur with respect to the quantifier?
radioGroup.radio: On either side of the quantifier, but not on both sides at the same time
On either side of the quantifier, or both sides at the same time
Before the quantifier, or on both sides at the same time
After the quantifier, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the degree words appear on either side of the quantifier?
radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side

form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark this type of quantifier with the feature makeQ. This will change their category to Q for the syntax. If a particular quantifier can only go with plural nouns or if it marks plural itself (such as many), add the feature plural to that entry.
Also, mark any words which can modify them with the features makeDeg modifies_Q. (If any of these degree words are the same as those which can modify an entire nominal phrase, you can simply add the additional feature modifies_Q to the same lexical entry.) Those which can only occur before the quantifier also need to have the feature QP-initial and those which can only occur after the quantifier also need the feature QP-final. Do not enter either feature QP-initial or QP-final on any degree words which can occur on either side.
